answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
To your second, I don't know of a formal "Recruitment Ethics" handbook. That would certainly be an asset. SHRM did publish an article on poaching in April: http://www.shrm.org/publications/hrmagazine/editorialcontent/2012/0412/pages/0412andors.aspx 
To your first question, I think not. Recruiting is about finding the best fit for each person and position, and your job may allow the candidate to do better and feel better. You are not doing anything deceptive or disrespectful.
Your candidate's short tenure is a red flag. What does he or she find unsatisfying about the current job? Why come to you? Is there a performance issue? Is there a risk of short tenure with you? But you can ascertain all of that with interviewing and reference checks. Go ahead and interview.
What do you think?

answers.author: Lawrence Di Re
answers.text:
If the position was properly advertised and the applicant responded to the advertisement no differently from any other candidate I don't see why you would not interview that applicant (presuming this applicant's experience, education and KSAs meet\exceed requirements).    
The applicant in question may have very good reasons for wanting to leave his\her current position that may only become clearer through the vetting of the interview process.  I would caution against a default that says "well I know the way the neighboring community does business, so something must be wrong with the applicant".   
In fact, the worst career advice I ever received I received from a range rider several years ago, precisely about the two-year commitment.  Unfortunate consequences can result from a rigid and myopic devotion to rules for rules' sake.    Hope this helps and happy to discuss particulars off-line, if you are interested.

author: Philip Rath
text:
I am in the process of filling a new position and received an application from an individual in the field who has been in their current position for less than a year.  They are one of the top applicants and if not currently employed by a neighboring community would get an interniew without question.  I do not believe they are member of ICMA and subject to a minimum two year committment to a community.  I plan to reach out to the applicant and offer mentoring, however, I struggle with the decision to interview.  
First is their any ethical issue with either interviewing an applicant working in a neighboring community and/or the applicant's tenure in that community?  
Second, is their an ethical guide to interview and/or hire the best applicants for the position?
title: Code of Ethics in Hiring
